messages.content:
You are a debugging assistant. You will be presented with a failing test, and tools (functions) to access the source code of the system under test (SUT). Your task is to provide a step-by-step explanation of how the bug occurred, based on the failing test and the information you retrieved using tests about the SUT. You will be given 9 chances to interact with functions to gather relevant information. An example answer would look like follows.

Title: Diagnosis of test `testGenerateURLFragment`
Details: The test `testGenerateURLFragment` checks whether HTML entities such as `"` are correctly escaped to their corresponding character by the `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` method. However, the test failure indicates that this is not the case. Following the execution path, we find that `StandardToolTipTagFragmentGenerator.generateToolTipFragment` is not escaping any HTML code; instead, it is using its input `toolTipText` as is. Consequently, un-escaped strings are being returned, which leads to the error demonstrated by the test.

After providing this diagnosis, you will be prompted to suggest which methods would be the best locations to be fixed. The answers should be in the form of `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` without commentary (one per line), as your answer will be automatically processed before finally being presented to the user.

The test `['org.apache.commons.math3.distribution.FDistributionTest.testIsSupportLowerBoundInclusive()']` failed.
The test looks like:

```java
346 :     @Test
347 :     public void testIsSupportLowerBoundInclusive() {
348 :         final double lowerBound = distribution.getSupportLowerBound();
349 :         double result = Double.NaN;
350 :         result = distribution.density(lowerBound);
351 :         Assert.assertEquals( // error occurred here
352 :                 !Double.isInfinite(lowerBound) && !Double.isNaN(result) &&
353 :                 !Double.isInfinite(result),
354 :                 distribution.isSupportLowerBoundInclusive());
355 :          
356 :     }
```

It failed with the following error message and call stack:

```
junit.framework.AssertionFailedError: expected:<false> but was:<true>
	at org.junit.Assert.fail(Assert.java:88)
	at org.junit.Assert.failNotEquals(Assert.java:743)
	at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:118)
	at org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(Assert.java:144)
	at org.apache.commons.math3.distribution.RealDistributionAbstractTest.testIsSupportLowerBoundInclusive(RealDistributionAbstractTest.java:351)
```

Start by calling the `get_failing_tests_covered_classes` function.

The failing test `org.apache.commons.math3.distribution.FDistributionTest.testIsSupportLowerBoundInclusive()` is part of the `org.apache.commons.math3.distribution` package. The test is related to the `FDistribution` class. Next, I will retrieve the methods covered by failing tests for the `org.apache.commons.math3.distribution.FDistribution` class. I will use this information to analyze the root cause of the failure.

messages.name: get_failing_tests_covered_methods_for_class
messages.content: [".isSupportLowerBoundInclusive()", ".density(double)", ".getSupportLowerBound()", ".FDistribution(double, double)", ".FDistribution(double, double, double)", ".FDistribution(org.apache.commons.math3.random.RandomGenerator, double, double, double)"]

The failing test `org.apache.commons.math3.distribution.FDistributionTest.testIsSupportLowerBoundInclusive()` covers the following methods in the `org.apache.commons.math3.distribution.FDistribution` class:
1. `.isSupportLowerBoundInclusive()`
2. `.density(double)`
3. `.getSupportLowerBound()`
4. `.FDistribution(double, double)`
5. `.FDistribution(double, double, double)`
6. `.FDistribution(org.apache.commons.math3.random.RandomGenerator, double, double, double)`

Let's take a look at the implementation of the `isSupportLowerBoundInclusive()` method in the `FDistribution` class to understand why the test failed. I will fetch the code snippet for this method.

The `isSupportLowerBoundInclusive()` method in the `FDistribution` class always returns `true`. This behavior does not match the expectation set in the test `testIsSupportLowerBoundInclusive()`, which expected `false`. This discrepancy in return values explains why the test failed.

To address the issue, the implementation of the `isSupportLowerBoundInclusive()` method in the `FDistribution` class needs to be adjusted to return `false` instead of `true`. This correction will align the method's behavior with the expectations of the test.

Based on the available information, provide the signatures of the most likely culprit methods for the bug. Your answer will be processed automatically, so make sure to only answer with the accurate signatures of all likely culprits (in `ClassName.MethodName(ArgType1, ArgType2, ...)` format), without commentary (one per line).
